name: Bangunan Sultan Abdul Samad
architects: A.C. Norman, R.A.J. Bidwell, A.B. Hubback
info: Once the largest building of its day, this administrative centre cost $198,000 Straits Dollars to build[cite: 18]. It used over 4 million bricks! The massive 140ft clock tower houses a one-ton bell that first chimed for Queen Victoria's birthday in 1897[cite: 23, 24, 25]. Look for the granite bollards near the porch—they were originally used for tethering horses[cite: 34].

quiz.q: What was the cost of the building in Straits Dollars? [cite: 18]

name: Old Post Office
info: Built at a cost of $100,000 Straits Dollars, this Moghul-style structure served as KL's General Post Office until 1984[cite: 39]. Designed by A.B. Hubback to match the Sultan Abdul Samad building, it features wide verandahs and pointed horse-shoe arches[cite: 39, 41]. It is now used by the Ministry of Tourism and Culture[cite: 38].

name: Wisma Straits Trading & Loke Yew Building
architects: B.M. Iversen (Loke Yew), A.K. Moosden (Chow Kit)
info: A cluster of commercial history. The Loke Yew Building is an iconic 6-storey Art Deco style structure designed by B.M. Iversen[cite: 55]. Next door is the Neo-Renaissance style Chow Kit & Co. Building (1905), featuring Flemish pediments[cite: 59, 60]. These sites mark the empire established by early tin tycoons like Loke Yew[cite: 53].

quiz.q: The Loke Yew Building is a 6-storey ___ style structure. [cite: 55]

name: Masjid Jamek
info: Built for $33,500 Straits Dollars at the confluence of the Klang and Gombak rivers[cite: 67, 64]. This Moghul-inspired mosque sits on an old Malay cemetery[cite: 68]. Admire the red and white brick bands and the flooring, which uses original Doulton tiles designed in the pattern of prayer mats[cite: 73, 76].

quiz.q: Masjid Jamek is located on the site of a Malay... [cite: 68]

name: Medan Pasar (Old Market Square)
info: The original town center of Kapitan Yap Ah Loy[cite: 79]. The square is lined with ornate 1907 Neo-classical shophouses. In the center stands an Art Deco Clock Tower featuring a 'sunburst' motif, built in 1937 to commemorate the coronation of King George VI[cite: 83, 84].

quiz.q: The 1937 Clock Tower commemorates the coronation of King ___ ___. [cite: 83]

name: Sze Ya Temple
info: KL's oldest traditional Chinese temple, founded by Kapitan Yap Ah Loy[cite: 88, 110]. Uniquely, it sits at an angle to the road to follow Feng Shui principles[cite: 90]. It is dedicated to the deities who guided Yap Ah Loy during the Civil War[cite: 110].

quiz.q: Who was the founder of the temple in 1864? [cite: 110]

name: The Triangle (Old Federal Stores)
info: Located at the Bangkok Bank Triangle[cite: 115]. The Old Federal Stores building is unique because it spans the entire block and has no 'five-foot way'[cite: 118]. It features fanciful garlic-shaped finials and was once occupied by the founders of Cycle & Carriage, who imported the first cars into Malaya[cite: 118, 119].

quiz.q: The unique Old Federal Stores building has no '___-foot way'. [cite: 118]

name: Kedai Ubat Kwong Ban Heng
info: Step back in time at No. 62. Established over 30 years ago, this traditional medicine shop retains its original glass cabinets and fittings[cite: 99, 100]. It is a living museum where you can still buy traditional herbs for everything from coughs and digestion to stress relief[cite: 102].

quiz.q: This shop was established over how many years ago? [cite: 100]

name: Oriental Building
info: When built in 1932, this 85-foot Art Deco masterpiece was the tallest building in Kuala Lumpur[cite: 105, 121]! Designed by A.O. Coltman on a triangular site, it features a beautiful curved façade[cite: 106, 121]. It originally housed Radio Malaya and later served as a bank[cite: 122].

quiz.q: In 1932, this was the tallest building in KL, at ___ feet high. [cite: 121]

name: Flower Garland Stalls
info: A feast for the senses located near the Teochew Association[cite: 124]. Here you can watch artisans weaving traditional fresh flower garlands used for religious offerings and celebrations. You can learn how to make one, or just buy a bunch of flowers[cite: 124].

quiz.q: You can learn how to make a traditional flower ___. [cite: 124]

name: Masjid India
info: Started as a timber hut in 1893 [cite: 126], the current Southern Indian style structure was opened in 1966 to hold 3,500 people[cite: 131, 132]. Unlike Masjid Jamek, services here are conducted in both Arabic and Tamil[cite: 135]. The surrounding arcade is famous for textiles, spices, and religious items[cite: 136].

quiz.q: Prayer service is conducted in Arabic and ___. [cite: 135]

name: P.H. Hendry Royal Jewellers
info: Malaysia's oldest existing jewellers, founded by P.H. Hendry from Sri Lanka after he was shipwrecked en route to Australia[cite: 138, 140]! The family became so renowned they were appointed Royal Jewellers to three different Sultans (Selangor, Kelantan and Negeri Sembilan) in the 1920s[cite: 146].

quiz.q: P.H. Hendry was appointed royal jewellers to how many Sultans? [cite: 146]

name: Panggong Bandaraya (Old City Hall)
info: Built for $107,000 Straits Dollars, this Moghul-style beauty housed the Municipal Offices and KL's only theatre auditorium[cite: 151, 153]. After surviving a major fire in the mid-1980s, it was restored as the Panggong Bandaraya[cite: 158]. It is now the venue for the musical MUD: Our story of Kuala Lumpur[cite: 158].

quiz.q: The building was razed by ___ in the mid-1980s. [cite: 158]

name: Dataran Merdeka
info: The historic cricket 'Padang'[cite: 264]. At midnight on August 31, 1957, the Union Jack was lowered here, marking independence[cite: 266]. Features include a 100m tall flagpole (once the world's tallest) and a Victorian fountain imported from England in 1897 for $4,000[cite: 269, 271].

name: National Textile Museum
info: Originally the Railway Offices (Cost: $116,000), this building is a classic example of 'Blood and Bandage' brickwork (red and white bands)[cite: 300, 303]. Designed by A.B. Hubback, it now houses a fascinating collection of Malaysian textiles[cite: 300, 302].

name: OCBC Building
info: A 1936 Art Deco gem by A.O. Coltman[cite: 309, 310]. It was innovatively designed with a basement bicycle garage[cite: 312]! Look up to see the stepped pylon and a mosaic panel featuring a Chinese Junk ship, the bank's original logo[cite: 314, 315].

name: Central Market (Pasar Seni)
info: Built in 1936 as the wholesale wet market for $330,000[cite: 317]. It used special 'Calorex' glass to keep the interior cool, saving the city from needing refrigerators[cite: 320]! In 1986, it was converted into the award-winning arts market[cite: 318].

name: Jalan Yap Ah Loy
info: A short street with huge history[cite: 328]. This road originally led directly to the home of Kapitan Yap Ah Loy[cite: 329]. It joins Jalan Hang Lekiu (formerly Klyne Street), which was once one of the only paved streets in the city[cite: 329].

name: Lebuh Ampang
info: Historically the street of the Chettiars (money-lenders)[cite: 337]. Look closely at No. 85—it features beautiful ceramic peacock tiles. The peacock is the symbol of Lord Muruga, the deity of the Chettiar caste[cite: 338, 339].

name: Jalan Melaka
info: A mix of old and new. Notable for the Bank Muamalat building, which was designed to look like a traditional Malay House despite being a modern banking hall[cite: 343]. The Malay school was originally located in this area[cite: 359].

name: Selangor Mansion & Malayan Mansion
info: Completed in 1964 for $2.5 million, these 8-storey blocks were an early experiment in mass public housing for the newly independent nation[cite: 348, 350]. They replaced the former squatters of Lorong Gombak[cite: 349].

name: Wisma Yakin
info: Built in the 1970s, this tower was once the tallest in the area[cite: 353]. It remains the absolute best place in the city to buy traditional Malay attire like Baju Melayu and Songkok (visit Stall 11 to meet En Zolfadli, the expert)[cite: 355, 356].

name: Jalan Melayu
info: Known as 'Malay Street'[cite: 358], this area was once filled with spice factories and bakeries. Look for the 100-year-old business selling 'Kain Pelekat' (sarongs) at No 3-5, run by the Kulasingam Chettiar family since 1895[cite: 361, 362].

name: Batu Road (Jalan TAR)
info: Now Jalan Tuanku Abdul Rahman, this was originally just a track leading to the tin mines at Batu Caves[cite: 364]. The stunning block of shophouses here (built 1912-1915) features giant pilasters and decorative plaster garlands[cite: 366, 368].

name: Old Survey Office
info: Another A.B. Hubback design built for $150,000[cite: 371]. It features a dramatic 400ft long arcade[cite: 372]. Look for the twin 'Chatris' (domed pavilions) on the roof[cite: 372]. It sits sadly beneath the modern LRT line but remains a stunning piece of architecture[cite: 373].

name: Old High Court
info: Costing $208,000, this 1915 building replaced the courts on the hill[cite: 376, 377]. It features a grand inner courtyard and was designed by—you guessed it—A.B. Hubback[cite: 376, 378]. It is currently awaiting restoration by Kraftangan Malaysia[cite: 382].
